title: Responsive Design with Bootstrap
author: Aifwen Stromblad
description: Bootstrap is a popular front-end CSS based frame work that is often used for designing responsive webpages. Furthermore, Bootstrap is very good at making websites that are functional for phones. Bootstrap is free and open-source, which makes it very useful for any software developer making web based applications. Bootstrap contains a lot of different components, specifically for CSS and JavaScript, which makes coding websites a breeze. One of it's most stand out features which makes coding easier has to be it's responsive grid system. It uses containers, rows, and columns to place content wherever you want on the webpage with ease. In addition, it can adapt to a multitude of screen sizes, whether small or large, another feature which makes it ideal for making webpages for mobile devices. Outside of the incredibly robust grid system, bootstrap also utilizes pre-designed components like modals, carousels, and navigation bars, features that, while they can be coded with JavaScript, normally take a lot more time to do well. Bootstrap also uses various easy to integrate JavaScript plugins, which brings with it various quality of life upgrades, like collapsible sections and tooltips. In addition, the CSS framework is not completely rigid, meaning that there is room for modulation. In particular, developers can change default styles through using Sass variables that the framework provides or by overriding the CSS. This means that one could use Bootstrap's underlying structure, which as previously mentioned is very robust, while simultaneously being able to create creative and detailed web designs that can impress whoever looks upon them. In summary, Bootstrap is a powerful web development tool that speeds up development and can maintain quality throughout many different web projects, thanks to it's components and it's ease of use. Without Bootstrap, coding a website would be a greater hassle then it is now.

title: HTML - an Introduction
author: Aifwen Stromblad
description:
HyperText Markup Language, or HTML for short, is a fundamental markup language used across the web to create and structure websites. Metaphorically, in the core web development trio that is HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, HTML are the building blocks, providing a structured base for CSS and JavaScript to build on. As such it is a vital cornerstone in web development, forming a skeleton for the other languages to animate and decorate into a beautiful website. HTML provides structure and organizes content through the use of tags and attributes, which help create structure and effects the way web content is presented. Elements on a page are created with tags that create specific elements, like '

' for paragraphs, '' for images, and '

' for the biggest header, for example. These tags form the Document Object Model (DOM) which is a tree-like structure that shows the hierarchical arrangement of whatever is on the web page. Then the attributes allow these tags to have special effects, use specific web or local resources or allow them to be manipulated by CSS or JavaScript. In addition, HTML uses semantic tags like '
', '
', and '
' that not only makes web content more accessible, but also makes it easier for search engines and other technologies to understand the web page, thus allowing it to gain more traction. In addition, using the '

title: CSS - an introduction
author: Aifwen Stromblad
description: Cascading Style Sheets, or CSS for short, is an important tool in web development that is used to layout and style web sites. In the important web development trio of HTML, JavaScript, and CSS, it's function allows it to make a website far more decorative and interesting, allowing said website to become aesthetically pleasing without too much hassle. CSS applies these aesthetic changes and styles to HTML elements using parameters known as selectors. These selectors can point to elements in general, or become more specific through an id or class. Once selected, then the stylistic changes from CSS can take hold. The kinds of changes that CSS can make range from things like color changes and font to spacing and positioning. But what if multiple selectors happen to select the same element? That's where the 'cascading' side of CSS comes in. The term comes from a priority scheme that decides where and when which styles apply if multiple rules target the same element. In addition, CSS is capable of controlling the layout of elements. This can be done through setting margins, padding, and borders. It can also be done through positioning elements with properties like flexbox, grid, and float. The grid and flexbox properties in particular can be used for creating more responsive layouts that can adjust to various devices and screen sizes. In times like these where mobile phones are becoming more and more useful for online browsing, having a website capable of doing such is crucial if not outright paramount. In short, CSS is an essential part of web design, as it's ability to enhance layouts and create aesthetically pleasing style changes to HTML elements make it crucial for anyone working on front-end development. Without it, all of our web applications would look drab and ugly, and we'd be miserable.
